title: @Riot question about upcoming updates
body:
How long does it take to prepare and ship out updates like the marksman update and the juggernaut update?

Does this mean that we will have to wait for a champions corresponding class to get updated before that champion does? (Im not sure how many more months of {{champion:107}}  I can take also I think {{champion:83}}  doesnt want to wait for juggernauts v2.)

These times around instead of trying to "suprise" us will you take a more transparent route so things like the Mordekaiser/Fiora fiasco can be avoided?

How many subclasses are there? immobile mages,diving fighter,Enchanter, Assassin ect.

replies.body:
Larger class updates like the Marksmen one take quite a bit of work, so we're probably looking at a couple of those a year. Immobile mages is what we've decided to focus on for the next one, and we'll have some early details on what that update will be focused on to share sometime this month. That'll look at stuff like goals, which characters we're planning to work on, rough timeframe etc, not specific kit changes. 

We will also have some individual reworks done separately from those class based ones still. Those will generally either be champions that need a complete overhaul with new kits, visuals, VO etc (Taric and Yorick for example) or champions that have some fundamental gameplay problems we need to address (we believe Ryze for example needs more than just balance adjustments to be both healthy and fun at the same time). We'll also occasionally do other small updates where a bit of extra bandwidth permits some opportunistic work, the Shen gameplay update for example which is getting pretty close. 

As far as the number of subclasses go we've got about a dozen we've been using internally. Plan is to tidy the definitions of those up a bit and throw them into a devblog for anyone that's interested.
Why are you getting downvoted?

Not sure. It could be that people don't feel that was a useful post. Or that they're frustrated at other things. Or that they don't feel this was an appropriate thread to respond to. Or that they don't agree with the direction the post outlines. Or something else entirely. Because of that lack of clarity I don't feel the upvote/downvote system's particularly useful for getting feedback overall, individual comments tend to be much more useful in that regard.
Well may I ask then, why do the posts on the State of the Season not have Red responses then?
they donÂ´t like to react to constructive criticism for some reasons...

As Fearless said once, Ritoers tend to avoid threads with too many landmines that they don't see a possibility of spin-doctoring propaganda that'll be met with anything remotely close to a positive response.  Take for example this thread that has angry responses from literally more than a thousand unique players and not a single red post:

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/riot-official/XeGzlzez-sona-update

When thousands of people have collectively decided they're right about something and you don't have any good news for them, it's generally not a good idea to try to speak rationally with them. But you can't just follow them like sheep, either, or the integrity of the game's design sinks. Best for Rioters to just stay away from threads like that one.
